name: Egusi Soup
description: Nigerian egusi soup made with ground melon seeds, palm oil, leafy vegetables (ugu or spinach), meat or fish, crayfish, and traditional spices. A protein-rich, thick soup commonly eaten with swallows like eba, pounded yam, or fufu.

sources.name: Calories in 100 g of Egusi Soup and Nutrition Facts - FatSecret

confidence_notes: Direct data from FatSecret. Micronutrients estimated based on typical ingredients: melon seeds (high protein, calcium, zinc), palm oil (vitamin A), leafy greens (iron, calcium, vitamin A).

name: Ogbono Soup
description: Nigerian soup made from ground ogbono seeds (African bush mango), creating a thick, mucilaginous texture. Prepared with palm oil, meat or fish, crayfish, vegetables, and traditional seasonings. The high water content makes it lower in calories than egusi.
confidence_notes: Calculated from serving size data (~224 cal/serving). High water content soup, so per 100g estimate is conservative. Micronutrients based on ogbono seeds (fiber, calcium), palm oil (vitamin A), and added proteins.

name: Efo Riro
description: Yoruba vegetable soup made with leafy greens (spinach, ugu, or sokoyokoto), tomatoes, peppers, palm oil, locust beans, meat, and fish. Rich in vitamins and minerals from the abundant leafy vegetables.
confidence_notes: Direct nutritional data from Fitia.app. High in iron, calcium, and vitamin A due to abundant leafy greens. Lower in calories due to vegetable base.

name: Pepper Soup (Goat)
description: Traditional Nigerian spicy soup made with goat meat, pepper soup spices (uziza, ehuru, uda), hot peppers, and minimal oil. A light, broth-based soup with aromatic spices, often served as an appetizer or consumed for its warming properties.
confidence_notes: Calculated from serving data (150-375 cal/serving). Broth-based soup with lean goat meat. Conservative estimate at ~90 cal/100g. Micronutrients reflect goat meat (protein, iron, zinc) and spices.

name: Suya
description: Popular Nigerian street food of thinly sliced beef or chicken marinated in yaji (groundnut spice blend with ginger, garlic, peppers) and grilled over charcoal. Served with onions, tomatoes, and cabbage.
confidence_notes: Data from SnapCalorie matches typical grilled meat with groundnut spice coating. Fat content from meat and groundnut powder. High protein and zinc from beef.

name: Akara
description: Deep-fried bean cakes made from blended peeled beans (black-eyed peas), onions, peppers, and salt. Crispy outside, soft inside. Popular Nigerian breakfast or snack item.
confidence_notes: Direct data from FatSecret. High calorie content from deep frying in oil. Protein and iron from beans. Micronutrients reflect bean base (iron, zinc, calcium) and frying oil absorption.

name: Moi Moi
description: Nigerian steamed bean pudding made from blended peeled beans (black-eyed peas), peppers, onions, and often containing eggs, fish, or crayfish. Wrapped in leaves or cooked in containers. Healthier alternative to akara.
confidence_notes: Data from multiple sources including 2025 research study. Lower in calories and fat than akara due to steaming method. Protein and micronutrients from beans and added eggs/fish.

name: Fufu (Cassava)
description: Nigerian swallow made from fermented cassava dough, boiled and pounded into a smooth, elastic consistency. Commonly eaten with soups in southeastern Nigeria.
confidence_notes: Data from NutritionValue.org (142-166 cal range, using mid-point). Low in protein and micronutrients. Primarily carbohydrate-based energy source. Fermentation may slightly reduce nutrients.

name: Pounded Yam (Traditional)
description: Traditional Nigerian pounded yam made by boiling and pounding fresh white yam tubers in a mortar until smooth and stretchy. Highly prized swallow, often served at special occasions.
confidence_notes: Nigerian-specific data from FitNigerian (109-118 cal range). Slightly lower than boiled yam due to water absorption during pounding. Traditional preparation method preserves most nutrients.

name: Puff Puff
description: Popular Nigerian deep-fried dough balls made from flour, sugar, yeast, and water. Sweet, fluffy inside with golden exterior. Common snack and party food.
confidence_notes: Data from SnapCalorie. High calorie density from sugar and deep frying. Primarily refined carbohydrates with minimal micronutrients. Fat content from oil absorption during frying.

name: Chin Chin
description: Popular Nigerian fried snack made from flour, sugar, butter, eggs, and milk, cut into small pieces and deep fried until crunchy. Common at parties and celebrations.

sources.name: Chin Chin Nutrition - Commercial Brand Analysis

confidence_notes: Based on commercial brand nutritional labels. High calorie and carbohydrate content. Fat from butter and frying oil. Calcium and vitamin A from milk, butter, and eggs.

name: Semovita
description: Nigerian swallow made from processed wheat semolina, mixed with hot water. Popular alternative to traditional swallows, lighter texture than eba or pounded yam.
confidence_notes: Direct data from Golden Penny brand packaging. Higher protein than cassava-based swallows. Values are for dry semolina; prepared semo has ~35% less calories due to water content. Often fortified with iron.

name: Ponmo (Cow Skin)
description: Processed and cooked cow skin, a popular protein source in Nigerian cuisine. Often added to stews and soups for texture. Primarily collagen protein.
confidence_notes: Data from FitNigerian. Unusually high protein value (46.9g) suggests dry weight or concentrated form. Fresh ponmo typically lower. Primarily collagen protein. Low in fat, minimal vitamins. Calcium from skin/bone tissue.

name: Zobo (Unsweetened)
description: Nigerian beverage made from dried hibiscus flowers (roselle), boiled with spices like ginger, cloves, and sometimes pineapple or citrus. Traditionally served cold. Rich in antioxidants.
confidence_notes: Unsweetened zobo data. Very low calorie beverage. Calories increase significantly with added sugar (typical sweetened version ~40-60 cal/100ml). Rich in vitamin C and antioxidants from hibiscus.

name: Kilishi
description: Northern Nigerian dried meat snack, similar to jerky. Thin beef slices coated with groundnut paste and spices, then dried and roasted. Concentrated protein source.
confidence_notes: Data from Green Baskit (400-413 cal, 40-55g protein range). Very high protein and calorie density due to drying process. Micronutrients concentrated from beef and groundnut coating. High zinc and iron from beef.

name: Fried Catfish
description: Catfish (often point-and-kill fresh from tank) marinated in spices, coated in flour or breadcrumbs, and deep fried. Popular in Nigerian restaurants and pepper soup joints.
confidence_notes: Data from Recipal food database. Calorie and fat content higher than grilled due to breading and frying. Catfish naturally high in protein. Micronutrients from fish (calcium, iron) and coating.

name: Palm Oil
description: Traditional Nigerian cooking oil extracted from oil palm fruit. Deep red/orange color from high carotene content. Essential ingredient in many Nigerian soups and stews.
confidence_notes: Pure fat with extremely high vitamin A from carotenes. Small amounts add significant calories and vitamin A to dishes. 50% saturated, 40% monounsaturated, 10% polyunsaturated fat.

name: Tuwo Shinkafa
description: Northern Nigerian swallow made from cooked rice mashed into a smooth, thick paste. Staple food in Northern Nigeria, commonly eaten with miyan kuka, miyan taushe, or other Northern soups.
confidence_notes: Nigerian-specific data from FitNigerian. Lower calorie than other swallows due to high water content in preparation. Essentially mashed rice with water, retaining rice nutrients but diluted.

name: Banga Soup
description: Niger Delta soup made from palm fruit extract, cooked with catfish or beef, banga spices (oburunbebe stick, ataiko, aidan fruit), and vegetables. Rich, oily soup with distinctive flavor.
confidence_notes: Conservative estimate for prepared soup. Banga concentrate is very high calorie (~510 cal/100g) but diluted significantly in soup preparation. Very high vitamin A from palm fruit. Actual values vary widely based on dilution and added ingredients.

name: Ugwu Leaves (Fluted Pumpkin)
description: Popular Nigerian leafy green vegetable (Telfairia occidentalis), used in soups, stews, and yam dishes. Highly nutritious, rich in protein for a vegetable, and packed with vitamins and minerals.

sources.name: Ugwu Leaves Nutrition - Multiple Nigerian Sources

confidence_notes: Data from multiple Nigerian nutritional sources. Exceptionally high in iron, calcium, and vitamin A. Higher protein than most leafy vegetables. Values for raw leaves; cooking reduces volume but concentrates nutrients.

name: Kunu
description: Northern Nigerian traditional beverage made from millet, sorghum, or rice, fermented with ginger and spices. Thick, refreshing drink, often sweetened. Popular during Ramadan.
confidence_notes: Research data for kunu on dry matter basis. As-consumed kunu is diluted, likely ~80-120 cal/100ml. Fermentation increases B-vitamins and digestibility. Micronutrients from millet/sorghum base (iron, zinc). Values vary significantly by grain type and dilution.

name: Afang Soup
description: Southeastern Nigerian soup made from afang leaves (wild spinach/Gnetum africanum) and waterleaf, palm oil, periwinkles, crayfish, and assorted meats. Nutrient-dense, vegetable-rich soup.

sources.name: Afang Soup Nutritional Estimate (based on 468 cal/serving)

confidence_notes: Estimated from serving size data (468 cal/~350-400g serving). High vegetable content provides excellent iron, calcium, and vitamin A. Protein from meats and periwinkles. Fat from palm oil and meats. Conservative mid-range estimate due to ingredient variation.
